sections.summary: The 'Default Fear' gauge. The spread measures the difference in yield between junk bonds and safe Treasuries.
sections.deep_dive: In 2026, High Yield spreads are the primary indicator for the 'Corporate Credit Cycle'. As companies face a 'Refinancing Wall', the stability of these spreads determines if the economy has a 'Soft Landing' or a 'Hard Landing'. Narrow spreads (under 300bps) signal a 'Search for Yield' and extreme complacency. Widening spreads (over 600bps) indicate that the 'Financial Plumbing' is clogging and companies are beginning to fail. For institutional investors, this is the 'Front Line' of risk; when spreads widen, equities always follow. It is the purest measure of 'Economic Survival' for the leveraged corporate world.

council_debate.macro: Direct correlation with the 'Unemployment Rate'. When spreads widen, companies start cutting costs.
council_debate.policy: The 'Implicit Fed Put'. The market believes the Fed will buy corporate bond ETFs during a systemic freeze.
council_debate.quant: Mean-reversion quants target spreads at the 800bps level for generational buy signals.
council_debate.technical: Watch for 'Spread Divergence'â€”stocks rising while credit spreads widen is a major warning of a top.
council_debate.geopolitics: Global credit contagion. If European junk bonds blow out, US spreads follow within days.
council_debate.tech: The rise of 'Private Credit' has hidden some of the stress, making the public spread a lagging but still vital indicator.

sections.forecast_risks: A 'Liquidity Cascade' where a single major tech default triggers a mass exit from high-yield ETFs.
sections.gms_conclusion: The definitive thermometer for corporate bankruptcy risk.
